Ooaman

I have no clue on this. I've heard of this term called "Gay-dar" where a person can tell a gay person from a mile away. I have been told that all people who are gay have it and some few people who are straight have it also. I think I am one of those many more straight people who do not have it. I honestly don't think I would know "gay" if it came up and stared me in the face. The truth is that I know at least five people that are supposedly gay (that I have personally met) and I never even knew it until someone told me. Some of them are people who have been described in ways simular to "shine to the brightness of many rainbows." Okay, not those words exactly, but something along those lines. So does "Gay-dar" really exist or are people simply making stuff up?
 
 Yes, I know this doesn't really have to do with gay rights so if someone complains to Admin and it gets moved to someplace better, I don't care.
joebrummer

Studies: Biology Influences Sexual Orientation AND Gaydar
 
 From Medical News Today, there's news of a biological basis for "gaydar," the rumored ability of some gay people to identify one another through poorly understood, non-verbal cues:
 
 Gay men preferred odors from gay men and heterosexual women, whereas odors from gay men were the least preferred by heterosexual men and women and by lesbian women. 
 
 Reference: Yolanda Martins, George Preti, Christina R. Crabtree and Charles J. Wysocki. Preference for Human Body Odors Is Influenced by Gender and Sexual Orientation. Psychological Science, September 2005 (not yet published).
 
 Meanwhile, the New York Times reports new evidence of biological underpinnings for sexual orientation:
 
 Using a brain-imaging technique, Swedish researchers have shown that men and women respond differently to two odors that may be involved in sexual arousal, and that homosexual men respond in the same way as women. ...
 
 The new research may open the way to studying human pheromones as well as the biological basis of sexual preference. The study, by Dr. Ivanka Savic and colleagues at the Karolinska Institute in Stockholm, is being reported in Tuesday's issue of the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
 
 But the studies do not mean that sexual orientation is necessarily fixed...
 
 From the Chicago Tribune:
 
 The current climate of debate over whether homosexuality is a matter of choice or is inborn makes such research extremely controversial, said team leader and neuroscientist Dr. Ivanka Savic of the institute's Center for Gender Related Medicine.
 
 "I want to be extremely cautious - this study does not tell us anything about whether sexual orientation is hardwired in the brain. It doesn't say anything about that," Savic said.
 
 For more information: Google News search
 
 Posted by Mike Airhart at May 9, 2005 11:14 PM
 Trackback Pings
 
 TrackBack URL for this entry:
 http://www.exgaywatch.com/blog/mt-tb.cgi/1822
 Responses
 
 Re: "Gay men preferred odors from gay men..."
 
 Well sure, if it's Halston, Hugo Boss or Paco Rabone... :-)
 
 Anyway... here we go again.
 
 Posted by: Anonymous at May 10, 2005 12:03 AM
 
 Very good update, Mike.
 
 I like your sense of balance, in that you also took the time to mention that the jury is still out with regards to whether orientation is fixed. This shows intellectual honesty.
 
 What role does smell really play in sexual arousal? It seems that at least for humans, a very large component of it is visual as opposed to olfactory, given the fact that men can get off quite well on pornography (minus the smell),while finding it quite difficult to get off on smell alone (minus the visuals).
 
 "Our findings support the contention that gender preference has a biological component that is reflected in both the production of different body odors and in the perception of and response to body odors."
 
 I don't doubt their findings. Sexual orientation, like everything else about us, DOES have a biological component, but I believe, as you probably do too, that we should not attempt to read anymore into this study than is warranted, in order to be intellectually sound.
 
 I would love to read the original article and evaluate the actual data, as I don't usually trust media sound bites, especially when they relate to issues like these.
 http://www.exgaywatch.com/blog/archives/2005/05/study_biology_i.html
Matthew S
Sometimes it is in their voice, walk, or look that one can tell.
Master_Shake

"Gaydar" isn't so much a natural thing as it is an learned thing. You just learn to pick up on certain things. And, being a leaned thing, it isn't flawless of course. There are certainly gay people who could pass as straight and straight people who might seem gay.
Ooaman

"Gaydar" isn't so much a natural thing as it is an learned thing. You just learn to pick up on certain things. And, being a leaned thing, it isn't flawless of course. There are certainly gay people who could pass as straight and straight people who might seem gay.

 So basically, if someone can't tell right away about someone, they may or may not be able to tell that in the future? I would like it to be specified that knowing if a person is gay or not is not what is important to me. As I said in my opener: There are some people that I have personally met that are gay but I had no idea they were gay. Then I shock people who are like "Yeah, they're gay" in a non-chalaunt type of way and I respond like "What, him!?"
 But if it is a "learned thing, it isn't flawless" then how would anyone really know for sure unless the person actually came "out of the closet" and said so? A guy could be effeminate and still be straight. A women could be butch or just simply be man-like and they could still be straight. So how would anyone really know for sure?

 I disagree thay it is learned. I think it is chemical. I think each persons body puts off scents and smells (pheromones) that let others know what they are, or are not attracted to. Women are generally not attracted to gay men. Why is that? Pheromones!
Master_Shake

I disagree thay it is learned. I think it is chemical. I think each persons body puts off scents and smells (pheromones) that let others know what they are, or are not attracted to. Women are generally not attracted to gay men. Why is that? Pheromones!

 If it's all pheromones, then some people wouldn't be better at knowing who is gay then others. You can have two straight women, one of whom can pick every gay man and lesbian out of a crowd and the other who wouldn't know a lesbian from a hole in the ground.

 Well from my point of view, this works. As I said earlier, I wouldn't know gay if gay stared me in the face. But from my point a view, I guess either could work. But with the idea that it is learned, this could also have some credit. Based upon the people that I already knew to be gay, I see people who may be gay. I say may be, because just because they seem that way doesn't mean they are. But the scent thing doesn't make sence to me. Would that suggest that a person can smell gay? I can understand a person looking or sounding (based on voice) gay, but how does gay smell?

 I think it exists to some degree. I tend to be 100% accurate, provided that I am not actively or passively looking for stereotypical identifiers. Once the idea of the possibility of gayness is planted in my mind, my gaydar doesn't work.

 there would be evidence for this if this was true. one's sexual preference does not cause the body to emit different pheremones. pheremones can be emitted when someone is sexually aroused, experiencing high adrenaline levels, and even in good or bad moods. but it has nothing to do with wether the person is sexually attracted to males or females. gay men do not emit any unique pheremones. 
 
 and straight women are often attracted to gay men because they are usually neat, mannerly, sensitive and witty, sometimes even if they think that the guy may be gay. look at the series "quer eye for the straight guy" where gays taught straight guys how to behave to be more attractive to women. women find lots of the traits in gay men very desirable. pheremones have nothing to do with it

 Hence my annoyance at all the guys I hang out with being both cute AND gay. I need to start hanging out with more straight guys. My gaydar keeps dragging me to all the gay ones though. I think mine works. I can be at a party and start talking to the only gay guy there. And I don't intend to "find a gay" it just happens. That is why my little title thing says "World's biggest f'ag hag": I become friends with every gay guy I come across.
